title: The Futurists - EPS_291: Whatâ€™s the end game with Tariffs? with Brett King and Robert Tercek

rawLines.text: this week on the futurists what happens
after the wrecking ball with Brett King
and Rob Terszik When it comes to what's
going to happen next in terms of
technology- based unemployment Musk has
been talking about it for many years now
talking about universal basic income
Bill Gates is saying we have to tax
robots and AI so that we can pay for UBI
But you know we've seen nothing in
Congress trying to figure out how we
might make that transition to this type
of society You've got technology going
like this in terms of its capacity to
inflict change on society and policy is
sort of like barely
[Music]
moving Hey there welcome back to the
futurist I'm Rob Tersik and my buddy
Brett King is joining me for a special
edition where we sort through the
wreckage of what used to be Western
civilization Uh seriously Rob it's like
um you know it often we get asked as
futurists what our predictions for the
future are And of course we talk about
the fact that we don't predict the
future we forecast and you know so forth
But the uh a follow-up to the Great
Depression it wasn't on my bingo card
for for this year Um but you know it
it's it's very interesting to sort of
look at this environment right now And
I'm amazed at how many
commentators on the right think that
tariffs might just work this time when
essentially never have trade wars ever
really uh you know given given any
advantage I mean the Smoot Holy Act we
know that that um was a key element in
uh the depression the 1930s depression
and um you know we have got literally
dozens of trade wars based on tariffs um
you know from pre20th century such as
the opium wars um the bisantine
Bulgarian war through to the banana wars
of the 18 late 1890s um the German
Polish Customs War um the Chicken War
which was a US versus EU um uh battle in
the 1960s and then um in the 21st
century Canada Australia with a salmon
trade dispute Um you know wherever we
look historically
uh trade wars like this have ended in
grief for all of the economies that
participated in it So it's like we have
hundreds of years of economic uh
evidence that trade wars don't work So
my question I guess that I'd like to
explore is given that very clear
economic evidence why why um uh pe
people like Peter Navaro and others
suggesting to Trump that this is a good
idea you know I mean what is the
motivation right now when the US economy
was actually doing very well we had the
lowest unemployment in um you know
decades um you know um obviously there
was the debt
uh debt imbalance and the debt problem
to fix but the US economy was in pretty
good health So why take it off the rails
like this with you know the stock market
crash and so forth What has to be the
motivation That's sort of really what
I'd like to get into into with you today
Yeah And after you erase $5 trillion of
of American wealth in one weekend you
better have a pretty good plan for an
outcome that's going to restore that
plus more right And that's what we're
not hearing about like there does not
seem to be a plan There doesn't seem to
be a clear vision of the aftermath It's
like well let's take a wrecking ball to
this really magnificent edifice and uh
of global trade and uh let's find out
what happens next We after we wreck it
we'll figure that out We'll put the
pieces back together I mean in a way
this is like Elon Musk's approach to
dealing with Twitter We're going to just
take out a wrecking ball We'll blow the
thing up and don't worry about it We'll
figure it out later Okay that works if
you're the richest guy in the world
because you can afford the losses
But that's not really the situation here
The United States borrows a lot of money
and we have to fund the government in
some fashion Even if they radically cut
you know overhead which they're tempting
to do but they're not going to get
anywhere close to their trillion dollar
target Uh it remains an open question
like so what what element of the economy
is going to be thriving after this to
fund all this change and the rebuild And
that is an entirely open question I
don't think there's anyone on either
party in the United States who's got a
good answer for it And we're getting
plenty of feedback from around the world
that this is a extremely poor idea This
is a very bad idea to embark on this I
mean you know the the sort of commentary
that frustrates me is oh people are
going to bend the knee and come to Trump
and and you know and cave on the tariff
situation This is not a functional even
if that was to happen this is still not
a functional solution to the core
problems in the US economy If you look
at what created this disparity um it was
the offshoring of production facilities
and um it's going to take um you know
trillions of dollars to onshore that
capacity back into the US and we're not
going to have you know like Vietnam who
was given what is it 45% tariffs the
other day um you know that they're
manufacturing clothes they don't they
can't buy
um US products at volume because they're
they're not affluent enough at the uh at
the core level of the economy and so
you're going to have a trade imbalance
there whatever happens now do Americans
really want to be going into factories
making socks and and you know and
t-shirts at four to five times the cost
of what it costs to get them from
Vietnam That's not reasonable So you say
all right well let's do robotic
factories and you know we're going to
create construction jobs with that and
robotic jobs and so forth you know for
that We're not actually inserting that
into the economy like in the way it was
during the sort of Henry Ford production
line era where people went into
factories and that really stimulated the
middle class It's not it's not clear
that bringing these factories back into
the US is going to create the sort of
jobs that the US can can field First of
all you know we don't have enough good
points there You know the com countries
we're trying to extract something from
aren't in a position to buy a lot of
American goods It's not just Vietnam
That's true for all those African
countries that just got whacked with
massive tariffs as well So they kind of
took a hamfisted approach or very
unsophisticated approach to calibrating
where you know there might be a case or
an argument for a fine-tune uh tariff
That's how they've been used typically
in the past to like you know identify a
specific issue uh usually one that
surfaces at the World Trade Organization
and they use the tariff as kind of a
scalpel This isn't a scalpel This isn't
even uh this isn't even a butcher's
knife This is just a sledgehammer So
that there's economic thermonuclear war
That's what it is And then the second
issue is like who's going to build a
factory right now with the level of
uncertainty that we have right now and
with Trump you know how many more years
is he going to be alive let alone
president three four max right nobody in
the right mind is going to say oh yeah
in the basis of this I'm going to go
invest a billion dollars and build a
robotic factory in the United States and
then the third point you made there is
robot factories don't necessarily create
very many jobs so the kind of
manufacturing that Trump is thinking
about this sort of mythological version
in the 1950s or something that's gone
and it's dead done It doesn't exist
anywhere right now in China Half the
robots in the world are in factories in
China They're doubling down on this on
on automated manufacturing We're nowhere
near we're not even in that game No I
mean there are ways we could have done
this You know we could have uh prepared
for this with let's say free STEM
education across the board We could have
given big tax breaks to corporations
building autonomous uh production plants
in the US That would have been a tax
break even the Democrats probably would
have supported Um and then we could have
used the tariffs in line with that
strategically or surgically to to create
incentives for uh specific industries
That that would have been an approach
that could have led to better on what
you're describing is what the chips act
that Biden introduced uh that's what the
chips act was designed to do and in many
respects it was successful It's it's you
know now it's being bashed daily by the
right wing in the United States but
that's just because it was Biden's idea
or his initiative Yeah The chips act was
designed to get America back in the
chips game in the in the semiconductor
business And there are a bunch of
strategic reasons for us having onshore
semiconductor manufacturing because we
want to you know mitigate the risk of uh
having manufacturing in in Taiwan And so
it was actually a strategic move as well
and it was surgical in the sense that it
was only aimed at that one industry So
it wasn't going to distort the whole
economy Unfortunately that's not what we
have here The tariffs on Taiwan Oh yeah
No it's the the Well guess who didn't
get the tariffs Like hm Russia and North
Korea Now what does that tell you Like
I don't know how I don't know how much
North Korea exports the United States or
or vice versa but for Russia a huge
amount of trade happening there but it
is a little bit weird that Trump whacks
our allies the hardest and he does it
every single time And to me there's
nothing strategic here This is what a
bully does A bully hits the people that
are nearest to him and the ones he knows
he can get away with it Uh he's not
really looking for a fight with a fair
rival He's looking for a fight with
somebody he knows he can beat And
unfortunately Canada and Mexico this is
like as much as we have tension in some
respects with immigration and and coming
from the south the big picture of the
20th century and 21st century with
Mexico and Canada is actually a
fantastic collaboration you know we
these are not defended borders these are
borders where uh trade and commerce flow
freely just the example of American auto
manufacturing it's really North American
auto manufacturing because the parts
move freely across the borders employs
millions of people or hundreds of
thousands of workers at least and uh and
now this has all been disabled it's
going to actually drive up the cost of
an automobile in the United States an
American car is going to cost a lot more
because of all the imported quality yeah
the other weird thing here is we've
we've kneecaped champions so Apple stock
famously got crushed Uh it went down 17%
at one point and that is because poor
Apple you know they've been trying to
diversify out of Chinese manufacturing
since the last Trump administration and
now they set up all these factories in
places like Vietnam And lo and behold
they're going to get whacked with
tariffs The cost of an iPhone is going
to go up by an estimated $300 per phone
So if an iPhone cost $1,000 today it's
going to be $1,300 phone tomorrow Not
because it's a better phone not because
of some new cool technology not because
of any innovation whatsoever just
because of these completely arbitrary uh
tariffs that have been imposed So that's
I mean that's a significant driver of
inflation And I don't think most people
have got their heads wrapped around this
The tariff is a tax It's the single
largest tax hike in American history And
that hasn't fully landed yet because we
haven't seen the price increases
Now there is some interesting elements
to this um you know the the yield curve
is down which could u make US treasury
bills more affordable um which could uh
you know be be a a a good thing for the
debt imbalance but you know to do that
at the cost of uh you know um US uh
businesses and and the US stock market
is is is a a huge risk Um the US dollar
in this situation it will tend to do a
little better because there's a flight
to the reserve currency from a security
perspective Gold's probably going to do
quite well Bitcoin struggling a bit
today but um you know could be seen as a
hedge there We'll have to sort of see
see what happens Um Cameron Winklvoss uh
you know commented on this the other day
that um we sort of saw a dislocation of
Bitcoin from the market but then today
Bitcoin's taken a pretty big hit or last
night um you know Bitcoin took a pretty
big hit So the the the rules um you know
the the the rules of what we have seen
happening historically in respect to you
know trade wars like this we are seeing
a lot of those trends uh sort of
repeating themselves in terms of
instability but you know my question is
why is this happening now and my theory
is twofold right is I think one is that
it could be something as simple as a
pump and dump scheme at a global level
in terms of um stock and trade that
explain what you mean before you go to
the second one Tell us what you mean by
the pump and dump So um you know what
you what you have this is sort of a
classic terminology in in stock trading
where you have someone visibly pump up a
stock you know to raise the price of a
stock and then um then you know once
it's exposed that it's all smoke and
mirrors the stock value plummets The
sell the high leave everybody else
holding the bag Yeah Exactly The
alternative to that is you dump on the
market you know something that lowers
the value you know incredibly and then
you buy in at the low point when
everyone is skittish about about the
stock So that that's a right This is
what the speculators did in the 19th
century with the stock market It was
like a game right They would spread
misinformation and drive prices up or
down and play the opposite Uh so buy on
rumor sell on fact right Yeah that's a
that's a it's a possibility right Um
because you know you have a bunch of uh
a bunch of people in there that you know
theoretically have the capability to
really move the market um you know when
it's at it low point But the other
element in terms of why now in terms of
the timing you know if you hear the
communication coming out of the
administration it's all about China
China China right you know and uh how
we're going to um pull back China Yeah
Pull back China you know from their how
dare they think they can compete with
the United States as an economy and so
forth And this is the last chance to to
stop China in their tracks and and sort
of basically teach them teach them an
economic lesson Well you know the
problem with that is that China has been
investing now for 10 years in
infrastructure in places like Africa Now
if you're an African you know uh
government in the current scenario even
with the tariff uh situation here are
you more likely to align yourself with
China who's been investing in your ports
and roads and um airports and
infrastructure over the last decade or
are you going to yield to the United
States who's now put this penalty of
tariffs on you This is the key problem
that the uh the US has the China's
ability to respond to these tariff wars
in terms of onshoring capacity that they
don't have currently is far superior to
the US So if this trade war is
successful in achieving you know what
the the administration thinks it can
with with China China's ability to
mobilize and reshape their economy uh
currently is much better than the United
States So they're likely to come out of
this significantly stronger But there is
a point that you collapse the yield
curve and the debt that China's holding
of the United States they have less
power over So this is sort of one of the
outliers there that this may be a sort
of way to renegotiate uh the US national
debt which clearly has been something
that that Musk has been focused on very
clearly over the last couple of years as
something that has to change But it
really kind
of do that Isn't it isn't it like saying
we're going to blow up this whole
economy in order to renegotiate the debt
And maybe maybe that's what's required
Maybe you have to take a hostage But
it's a little strange to put a gun to
your own head and say I'm going to blow
this thing up in order to renegotiate I
I I have a hard time understanding why
the Chinese would say fine with that Um
and bear in mind the context for this
China has greatly surpassed United
States ability to manufacture But that's
not all They now China's capacity in
manufacturing rivals that of the entire
world Certainly Europe and the United
States combined and they're investing
they continue to double down investment
where we're not investing anything in
manufacturing It's a tiny amount you
know the the the chips act like I said
it took a act of Congress uh to even
generate interest in in onshoring u chip
manufacturing and that's just one aspect
of manufacturing where in China this is
going on across the board Uh in the last
5 years the Chinese government has
redirected government uh investment and
loans towards manufacturing and away
from real estate which is probably a
really smart move on the Chinese
government's part But that means that
there's an enormous amount of capital
available to deploy now in robotic
factories and they're going for it
That's internal to China Like that is
totally not subject to any of the
dynamics that we're talking about
Nothing this administration is doing
none of these tariffs are going to have
any impact on that And so while the
United States is pissing off all of its
allies and trading partners and blowing
up the international uh trade policy uh
China's doubling down on its ability to
export at low cost and continue to be
the workshop for the world I don't
really see how this ends up working well
for us No no I don't I don't see that
either I was uh I I was at NECA Island
with uh Richard Branson um one week ago
as you know we had a fintech event there
and I was invited to speak and I talked
with him about this um he was not very
like this was pre the tariff
announcement but you know he saw he saw
this uh this sort of stuff coming and he
was um you know not very complimentary
of the US's chances of fixing this
problem without real structural reform
in terms of really thinking about you
know what you know what the future of
the United States needs to look like and
investing in that and that's I think
that's the key problem here is that
you've got Um oh and the other thing is
that that if you look at Taiwan Taiwan
is a huge risk um because of China's
aspirations there But we were discussing
that maybe China might not do like they
might not go in militarily and take over
Taiwan What if they formed an economic
alliance with Taiwan like the EU
Something like that is very possible
that could really cut the US out from
from the chip side of things And you
know uh they uh China just uh launched a
couple of um fabrication uh facilities
for chips in the last couple of months
in China Things that they weren't
supposed to be able to do for another
few years um you know based on the chips
act So as you say China's responding to
this in the way we'd expect with massive
investment in um you know uh
infrastructure inside China to be able
to compete and they've invested in a lot
of countries in the region and you know
across in Africa as well uh to uh
encourage trade and it seems like that's
going to be you know um quite a smart
move given the current environment
Almost anyway this comes out China's
going to be ahead because their their
production capacity is going to be
increasing throughout this trade war
however long it lasts where I don't see
any American company making a decision
to invest in the United States because
of the uncertainty You we have such an
uncertain environment and as you point
out it's not just uncertainty bas you
know the crazy whim of a president that
just wakes up one day and decides to
issue an executive order It's also the
uncertainty of interest rates and the
uncertainty of trade policy and the so
and the uncertainty of the inputs right
Because of the because of the tariffs um
because no one knows anything So
everybody is holding back on making a
making a decision Meanwhile China's
doubling down on investment So they're
going to move ahead while we are
paralyzed with indecision This I view as
a real problem The longer this persists
the worse that problem gets Brett give
me a hopeful scenario like what's the
good outcome here that that I I I find
it kind of fanciful to to launch a trade
war and expect a good outcome for the
reasons you said at the beginning of the
show The history suggests that there's
never a good outcome But what is it they
expect to get So one of the points you
made is that if uh if the yield curve
goes down and treasuries get cheaper or
the interest rates pay to go down that
may somehow reduce American uh the the
debt burden the United States has if if
if the US uh if the US economy suddenly
you know fires then they could buy back
some of that debt you know but that's
unlikely because um you know if the sort
of investment that's required
particularly in infrastructure to build
autonomous factories you know even the
infrastructure bill that um Biden
introduced hasn't even made a dent in
that sort of stuff and as as we've
talked about on the show before the uh
you know even the dock workers and the
deal that was done with the dock workers
is to avoid automation in US docs shows
that we're not really of of a structural
mindset to do that sort of level of
automation for onshoring robotic
factories and uh you know autonom
autonomous supply chain So that's uh
that's the the the risk But the the
positive could be that it really does
force a real structural rethink in terms
of the way the US economy is going to
compete because if this doesn't work
this is like the nuclear option to slow
China down And when this doesn't work
then it will have to be we need real
reform and AI and uh you know technology
and robotics is is going to be that But
we need to massively invest in that But
that means breaking um you know the
control of uh sort of incumbent um you
know lobbying groups and things like
that you know in in the US Okay So
that's a fundamentally undemocratic
approach to having a discussion about n
national economic policy Uh effectively
what what this group is doing is they're
saying you know what we're not asking
for permission We're just going to break
the glass and then we'll pick up the
pieces afterwards and they'll force it
It'll be a fade to complete where now
it's like we have to rebuild the economy
in a new way probably in a way that
disempowers labor and labor unions
probably in a way that enriches a
handful Uh so what starts to what it
looks like to me coming out the other
side of this in the scenario you said
United States starts to look more like
Brazil or Argentina uh where a handful
of families that are wealthy own
everything and everybody else is working
for the man and buying at the company
store Let's play this out after the
break But you know in terms of the
different scenarios that are possible
but I I certainly think you know let's
get into um the the the thinking that AI
climate quantum all of these things that
are coming for this sort of uh
inflection point in human society
Maybe that is triggering this because
maybe they know that there's sort of
momentous changes coming in in human
society and they're trying to grab as
much control uh of of the assets and and
wealth before grab as many assets as you
can It's a smash and grab Okay folks
You're listening to the futurist with me
Rob Tersik and my co-host Brett King
We're going to be right back after a
short break Don't go anywhere because
this is going to be a great conversation
Hey welcome back to the futurist I'm Rob
Turszik with Brett King And Brett before
the break we were talking about the
scenarios Actually we were trying to
talk about positive possible positive
scenarios although we were struggling to
come up with any but you had a second
thought about what this wrecking ball
might achieve or what it might
accomplish for a future economy Tell me
more about that H well I mean this is
sort of as we discussed in the first
half this is sort of the economic
thermonuclear option for trying to stock
China and its economic process you know
we progress rather we we know that China
on a uh purchasing power parody basis
has already surpassed US GDP and you
know with their investment in the belt
and road and energy sector and so forth
you know there's a fairly strong
likelihood not only that they'll be able
to compete with the US in the 2030s but
surpass the US particularly with the
looming debt cliff problem we've talked
about this on the show previously but
this is as I say the nuclear option if
this doesn't work it has to force to
rethink in terms of what should the
nature of the US economy be to compete
with China If we haven't been able to
stock China you know we as the west and
th this as the thermonuclear option
fails then the only choice is to compete
with China on their terms And this means
massive investment in rethinking
infrastructure in the United States I'm
not talking about you know um $5
trillion of investment And I'm talking
20 or $30 trillion of investment over a
number of years I I'm talking about
upgrading uh transportation systems the
entire energy grid you know sort of
rethinking this and getting ready for a
world of the you know the smart
economies autonomous supply chain AI
based systems and so forth But that
requires breaking the back of the
lobbying groups and the oligopolies that
have control over the sort of the the
industrial 20th century economy in the
United States today But it's going to
take a shock like this to sort of make
that restructuring happen I think
because it's like they sent off a
grenade and now they're going to try to
pick up the pieces after the Brett
Here's a question for you though The
country is already up We're swimming up
to our eyeballs in debt as a nation in
the United States right now That's at
the heart of this issue And what you're
talking about is 20 or 30 trillion
dollars of investment Where will that
come from And what investor will trust
the United States after this spectacular
display of bad decisionm Who's going to
feel confident about investing $20
trillion in the US to reboot our economy
Well this is a point And and how do you
do that in the current debt situation
that that you know um one of the things
we explored in um the book the rise of
technosocialism
was there a way to cancel out um US
national debt smartly and the what we
played with was that as climate um costs
increase as the economic loss from
extreme weather events and climate
increases and we see the ballooning e
eco refugee problem there's a pretty
good argument to sort of cancel all
national debt to reinvest in solving
those problems right So that could be
something that not the current
administration um would could champion
but a a new administration coming out of
this could say "Let's get the world."
That's a great idea if you're the debtor
It's not so great if you're the lender
on the other hand No but um this this
requires much more consensus based
operation right And I think you know in
a situation where um you know if you
think about China China doesn't want
global instability and eco refugees
anymore than the US does So you know
there there is uh you know the
investment that China is making in um
green energy for example I know there's
a lot of criticism about their carbon
output but let's remember that a lot of
the carbon output in China is producing
goods that go to the west right So we
can't blame them for that if we're
buying all this stuff made in Chinese
factories But the rate of them um
retooling their energy systems is truly
impressive You know they deployed half
of the world words world solar energy
last year alone So they're getting
something like 90% of the solar panels
in the world as well And they do it more
cost effectively than any American
company possibly can Uh so you know one
of the things that's interesting about
the the scenario you're raising is for
that scenario to work the United States
would have to become more like China And
you and I have debated about China in
the past on several episodes And you're
you're very bullish about China's
economic prospects I get that And I've
always been very skeptical about China
as a governing uh you know as a
government I wouldn't want to be a
citizen of a country that was that
controlling So we've had that
conversation going on But what's
happening in the United States right now
in parallel is getting closer to China
as an autocratic system right It's
becoming a kind of a mix like a blend of
autocracy and democracy and already
we've kind of our president current
president is neutralized Congress
They're functionally ineffective Uh a
lot of what Congress power held as power
to check the president has been seated
to the president to the executive
executive orders Yeah Yeah And now he's
also uh he's got the Supreme Court on
his side And some some would speculate
that he's got some measure of control
over the judiciary I'm not so sure if
that's true but nevertheless what you're
seeing is a concentration of power in
the hands of one man who's backed by the
richest man on the planet who has
already indicated that he's willing to
spend an unlimited amount of money to
back candidates in for Congress whether
it's for the House or Senate uh if there
are if there are candidate if there are
people sitting in the Senate today or in
the House that do not comply with
Trump's wishes then um then they're
going to get
primar supporter by a MAGA person in the
future and uh Musk has made it clear
he'll spend an unlimited amount of money
to do that So you've got power and money
combined and don't forget that the
people who were invited to President
Trump's inauguration were among the
richest people in the United States uh
see it's sort of like a parade of
oligarchs in the United States and this
is a very unamerican kind of concept
that oligarchs are there with at the
White House celebrating with the
president um but it does look an awful
lot like Russia and China and so it
seems to me is that as we are in this
kind of battle have fallen into line
right like look at Zuckerberg I mean Tim
Cook has been a bit quieter though they
did uh cave on on um some some elements
although they have protected diversity
but you know Chamath um you know um and
and others you know seeing their sort of
turnabout in in terms of their uh
communication is you know b bending the
need of the administration is pretty
shocking now um so you got bank capital
and big tech and of course the banks are
falling into line as well uh so so he's
consolidated great although although
Jamie Diamond has not been positive
about the tra the tariff situation he's
been quite uh vocal in his uh
um nonsup support of uh the tariff
situation lead to a global recession you
know etc etc I don't think he he can
move the needle though obviously No On
his own what difference does it make He
the dog can bark and the caravan still
moves on I I think what we're starting
to see is a United States that looks
distinctly unamerican in the 21st
